Description: Egyptian terracotta female (?) figure in Egyptian style. Part of torso with hands on breasts, left arm missing, broken at neck and waist. Hollow and mould-made with traces of a white coating. Ridge on top where head would have been joined. Vent hole running through it of 4mm diameter at its smallest at neck. Brown Nile silt with fine gold mica, black and white inclusions.
Curator's comments: Higgins suggests this Egyptian style figure was made in Naukratis (Higgins 1954, 405), though the Nile silt fabric is too generic to specifically attribute to Naukratis. The groove on the underside was intended to fit onto the ridge of the body, such as on a smaller figurine parallel GR1886,0401.1422, dated to the same period. See the parallel NA620 from Naukratis now in the Cambridge Museum of Classical Archaeology. A similar figurine from Gela Acropolis is dated between 650 and 640 BC (Stampolidis 2003, 384, no.577 Archaeological Museum of Gela inv. no. 8378). Stampolidis, N.C. (ed.), 2003, Sea Routes…From Sidon to Huelva. Interconections in the Mediterranean 16th-6th c. BC. Athens.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (1544)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DC.279) (Phase 1)
Acquisition name: Donated by: Egypt Exploration Fund (Committee of)
